intro: Bupleurum sibiricum, commonly known as Siberian angelica, is a perennial herb native to the cold climates of Siberia and Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its finely divided leaves and umbel-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows to a height of 60–120 cm, with a stout, hairy stem and compound leaves that are often bluish-green in color. Its small white or pale yellow flowers bloom in late spring to early summer, attracting various pollinators. The roots of Bupleurum sibiricum are used in traditional medicine for their purported anti-inflammatory and antispasmodic properties.
